model_input:
[Task Description]
You will be given DIALOGUE CONTEXT and MEMORY.
You task is to evaluate MEMORY based on the criterion.
Please make sure you read and understand these instructions carefully. Please keep this document open while reviewing, and refer to it as needed.

[Criterion]
Helpfulness (1-5): How much the MEMORY provides helpful information for a language model, representing Speaker B, to generate a proper next response based on DIALOGUE CONTEXT. An helpful memory should contain sentences that are naturally structured, representing the development (e.g., causality, connection, etc) of two speakers' past interactions. These sentences should be phrased in a way such that the language model can easily identify important contextual cues related to DIALOGUE CONTEXT.

For your information:
A score of 1 means that most sentences in MEMORY do not benefit generating a next response OR are structured in a way that does not really tell us much about two speakers' past interactions (e.g., connection, relevancy, or development of events).
A score of 5 means that MEMORY contains some sentences providing information relevant to DIALOGUE CONTEXT. And, sentences in it should be naturally connected so the development/causality/relevancy of sentences is clearly demonstrated. Even the sentences that are not related to DIALOGUE CONTEXT are naturally phrased such that the language model can easily identify them as not beneficial.

[Evaluation Steps]
1. Read DIALOGUE CONTEXT and MEMORY carefully.
2. Rate MEMORY on a scale of 1-5 according to the criterion above.
3. Provide a brief explanation for your rating.

[Your Task]
DIALOGUE CONTEXT:
Speaker A: I was able to get the aluminum sheeting for my garbage. I'm going to install it today and I'll let you know how my raccoon problem goes.  Speaker B: I hope it goes well for you. How come you don't just leave small bowls of food out and befriend the raccoons? It would solve your problem a lot faster, especially because raccoon's are so smart. Bandicoot knows how to open and unlock so many things, it's makes it difficult to keep him out of trouble. Which is why I take him to work with me. Speaker A: Ohhh.  That would be bad. I really do not want more raccoons or other animals coming around.  I like them OK, but I do not want to have some diseased ones get close to the house.  Speaker B: Understandable. Have you ever tried contacting animal control? That's how I got Bandicoot. I was working that day and animal control came by explaining about needing fosters for raccoons. I thought it was weird, so I did it and began to work at the small raccoon cafe that is part of the zoo. I love it.  Speaker A: That is a good idea.  Maybe they could help move them to a safer area.  I have a lot of traffic around and they could get hit if they are coming to my place all the time.  Have you been able to teach your raccoon any tricks? Speaker B: The only trick I was able to teach him, that I deeply regret, was how locks worked. I thought it was cool at first, you know, to see a raccoon unlock a door. And now, I regret it so much. I've had to change the layout of my apartment and put deadbolts on my doors so that Bandicoot can't get out. And, he is sneaky about it. One time, he unlocked the pantry and was eating some cookies! It's like having a toddler that never grows up. Speaker A: That is bad I guess.  Do you keep all of your chemicals, poisons, and medications up and locked?  I would hate to think what might happen if Bandicoot got into any of that.  Hey, when you drive do you lock him up in a cage or let him wander around in the car?  That could be dangerous for you driving and he freaks out.

MEMORY:
1. Speaker B works at a Raccoon Cafe and takes care of Bandicoot, a raccoon.
2. Speaker B has been taking care of the raccoon for over a month and is interested in training it.
3. Speaker B believes raccoons can make good pets if cared for properly.
4. Speaker A is dealing with a raccoon problem and plans to buy aluminum sheeting to cover up holes.
5. Speaker B considers raccoons intelligent and funny.
6. Speaker A has not interacted closely with raccoons but admires them.

[OUTPUT]
Helpfulness Score:

memory_text:
1. Speaker B works at a Raccoon Cafe and takes care of Bandicoot, a raccoon.
2. Speaker B has been taking care of the raccoon for over a month and is interested in training it.
3. Speaker B believes raccoons can make good pets if cared for properly.
4. Speaker A is dealing with a raccoon problem and plans to buy aluminum sheeting to cover up holes.
5. Speaker B considers raccoons intelligent and funny.
6. Speaker A has not interacted closely with raccoons but admires them.
speaker: Speaker B
raw_prediction: Oh, absolutely! Safety first. I make sure to keep all hazardous items securely locked away. As for driving, Bandicoot has his own little carrier that's strapped in with a seatbelt. It keeps him safe and secure during car rides, and he seems to enjoy looking out the window. It's definitely important to consider safety for both of us on the road.
prediction:
Helpfulness Score: 4

The MEMORY provides relevant information that could aid Speaker B, represented by the language model, in generating appropriate responses within the DIALOGUE CONTEXT. The memory effectively highlights the key aspects of the conversation, such as Speaker B's experience with raccoons, their admiration for raccoons' intelligence, their involvement with a raccoon cafe, and specific issues pertaining to Speaker A's raccoon problem. The MEMORY could be slightly more helpful by including details on past interactions or events between Speakers A and B that are directly connected to the current context. The sentences are clear and structured logically, providing a solid base for generating responses connected to the context.
